LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
 
Targeting classification: Targeted intervention  
Sector: Finance 
Subsector: Finance sector development  
Themes: Sustainable economic growth; governance; gender and 
development 
Subthemes: Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets; 
financial and economic governance; gender equity in opportunities 
 
Category  C.  An  environmental  assessment  of  the  policy  matrix  is 
available as Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
Although  annual  economic  growth  in  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic 
Republic  (Lao  PDR)  has  averaged  nearly  6%  in  recent  years, 
contributing  to  a  reduction  in  the  poverty  rate  from  45%  in  1992/93  to 
32%  in  2002/03,  this  growth  has  been  unevenly  distributed.  Rural 
inhabitants comprise 72% of the total population, but about 90% of the 
country’s  poor  live  in  rural  areas.  Maintaining  high  growth  rates  in  the 
rural  sector  will  be  a  critical  factor  in  achieving  the  Government’s 
development and poverty reduction goals. 
 
A  dynamic  rural  economy  requires  sustainable,  market-oriented  rural 
and  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  that  can  intermediate  between 
savers  and  borrowers,  efficiently  allocate  resources,  and  facilitate 
production  and  the  exchange  of  goods  and  services.  However,  the 
outreach  of  formal  financial  services  remains  extremely  low.  Per  its 
records,  the  Agriculture  Promotion  Bank  (APB)  provides  credit  and 
savings services to about 120,000 (or 14%) of the country’s estimated 
900,000  households.  However,  a  survey  of  1,189  households  done  in 
early  2004  indicated  that  only  1.95%  had  borrowed  from  APB  in  the 
previous  12  months,  confirming  that  the  bulk  of  APB’s  current  clients 
are  urban.  MFIs  are  virtually  nonexistent,  and  the  four  largest  reach 
only  6,000  clients  collectively.  Savings  mobilization  is  also  low.  Less 
than  15%  of  households  have  a  savings  account  in  the  formal  sector, 
and  over  90%  of  savings  in  formal  financial  institutions  are  held  by 
urban clients. 
 
Although  the  Lao  PDR  faces  special  challenges  due  to  its  dispersed 
population and limited infrastructure, which adds to the cost of financial 
intermediation, institutional weaknesses and Government policies have 
contributed to low outreach of the sector. APB has primarily channeled 
Government  and  aid  funds  to  targeted  clients  at  subsidized  interest 
rates. Management autonomy and responsibility have been limited, and 
APB’s financial performance has been poor. APB’s outreach has been 
limited  because  its  losses  have  prevented  it  from  building  up  its  own 
capital,  Government  and  aid  financing  are  limited,  and  APB’s  weak 
financial condition has prevented it from mobilizing commercial funding. 
APB’s  subsidized  interest  rates  have  also  crowded  out  MFIs  and

regulatory framework has discouraged many microfinance practitioners 
from  investing  in  the  sector.  Policy  and  institutional  reforms  will  be 
necessary for rural and microfinance to achieve its potential to catalyze 
growth and reduce poverty in the Lao PDR. 
 
The goal of the Rural Finance Sector Development Program (RFSDP) 
is to assist the Government to reduce poverty and promote sustainable 
economic  growth  in  rural  areas.  RFSDP  will  contribute  to  this  goal  by 
achieving  its  objective  to  promote  a  sustainable  and  market-oriented 
rural and microfinance sector. It will assist the Government to improve 
transaction  costs 
including 
the  sector’s  performance, 
associated  with  delivery  of  financial  services,  and  thereby  increase 
sustained  access  to  financial  services  by  the  rural  poor  and  micro, 
small,  and  medium-size  enterprises.  Rural  finance  clients  will  have 
opportunities  to  increase  incomes  and  employment  and  improve  their 
quality  of  life  through  access  to  strengthened,  sustainable,  and  more 
responsive rural and microfinance services that support investment and 
production.  The  increased  access  to  capital  will  encourage  farmers, 
nonfarm rural households, and agribusinesses to invest and create job 
opportunities. 
 
The program loan has four components: (i) creating an enabling policy 
framework  for  public  and  private  provision  of  rural  and  microfinance 
services;  (ii)  creating  a  sound  prudential  regulatory  and  supervisory 
environment  for  public  and  private  rural  and  microfinance  institutions; 
(iii) transforming APB into a financially self-sustainable, market-oriented 
rural  finance  institution;  and  (iv)  creating  a  supportive  nonprudential 
regulatory  environment  for  rural  and  microfinance.  Specific  policy 
measures and outputs will include adoption of a new national policy for 
the  rural  finance  sector;  reforms  in  APB  to  transform  it  into  a 
sustainable,  market-oriented  rural  finance  institution,  including  greater 
transparency,  improved  governance,  and  phasing  out  policy  lending; 
performance-based  recapitalization  of  APB;  an  improved  supervision 
regime for APB; and enabling, best-practice regulations for MFIs. 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  provide  a  loan  of  $7.684 
million equivalent from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance 
the  Program.  The  loan  will  have  a  repayment  period  of  24  years, 
including a grace period of 8  years. An interest rate of 1%  per annum 
will be charged during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter. 
 
The proposed program loan will be released in three tranches. The first 
tranche of $2.7 million equivalent will be released on loan effectiveness; 
the second tranche of $2.5 million equivalent about 15 months after the 
first  tranche;  and  the  third  tranche  of  $2.484  million  equivalent  about 
18 months  after  the  second  tranche,  subject  to  compliance  with  the 
conditions for their release.

In  association  with  the  project,  the  Japan  Fund  for  Information  and 
Communications Technology (JFICT) approved a grant of $472,000 for 
upgrading ICT and MIS at the APB. The JFICT grant will assist APB to 
(i)  upgrade  its  ICT  human  resources’  capacity  to  manage  the  ICT 
systems  upgrade;  (ii)  review  and  confirm  the  systems  specifications; 
(iii) plan and execute the bidding, selection, and contracting processes 
with  the  turnkey  contractor;  (iv)  monitor  the  turnkey  installation; 
(v) prepare  and  carry  out  a  training  plan;  (vi)  review  and  evaluate  the 
effectiveness  of  technical  and  operational  training  provided  under  the 
turnkey contract; and (vii) plan and implement the rollout of systems to 
the  whole  APB  branch  network.  Consulting  services  of  11  person-
months (5 international and 6 domestic) will be required. 
 
At  a  macroeconomic  level,  the  Program  will  result  in  a  deepened 
financial  sector  and  greater  financial  intermediation  that  will,  in  turn, 
result  in  a  more  efficient  allocation  of  resources.  The  phasing  out  of 
policy  lending  from  APB  will  enable  the  Government  to  realize  much-
needed budgetary savings; and the transfer of residual policy lending, if 
any,  to  an  on-budget  mechanism  will  increase  transparency  and 
improve monitoring, thus enabling the Government to better assess the 
costs and benefits of such lending. Indirectly, the stimulus to enterprise 
created  through  enhanced  outreach  of  credit  will  result  in  increased 
investment  and  job  creation.  The  increased  outreach  of  savings 
services will encourage monetization. 
 
Microfinance providers and sponsors will benefit from the Government’s 
adoption  of  an  enabling  and  transparent  regulatory  and  supervisory 
regime.  The  formalization  of  the  microfinance  sector  will  act  as  a 
stimulus to private investment in the sector. 
 
Farmers,  other  rural  inhabitants,  and  rural  enterprises  will benefit  from 
improved  access  to  credit  and  savings  services.  Income  benefits  will 
accrue 
intensification  and  expansion  of  production  and 
acquisition  of  new  technology.  Business  start-up  and  expansion  will 
lead to job creation, for both the self-employed and wage earners. 
 
The  RFSDP  will  strengthen  the  rural  finance  sector  and  promote 
sustainable  delivery  of  financial  services  in  rural  areas.  The  improved 
policy  and  regulatory  environment  supporting  rural  and  microfinance 
institutions will promote the establishment and operations of sustainable 
microfinance  and  other  rural  financial  institutions,  including  those 
established  by  the  private  sector  and  international  development 
agencies.  These  institutions  will  provide  the  rural  poor  with  alternative 
and  more  affordable  options  compared  with  informal  sources,  which 
often  charge  monthly  interest  rates  of  10%  or  higher.  The  RFSDP  will 
foster demand-driven, sustainable rural financial services. International 
experience shows that the poor are willing to pay market interest rates 
and value-sustained access more than a subsidized interest rate.

Restructuring  APB  will  have  both  direct  and  indirect  positive  social 
benefits.  Directly,  APB’s  transformation  will  enable  it  to  increase 
outreach  and  contribute  to  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  in 
the  Lao  PDR.  International  and  Lao  experience  have  shown  that  the

the poor disproportionately. Indirectly, phasing out directed lending and 
interest  rate  subsidies  from  APB  will  free  up  scarce  resources  in  the 
Government  budget,  which  can  contribute  to  better-targeted  poverty 
interventions and reductions in the Government deficit, thus contributing 
to macroeconomic stability. If residual policy lending is shifted to an on-
budget  nonbanking  mechanism,  the  enhanced  transparency  will  allow 
policy makers to better assess the costs and benefits of such lending.

The  lack  of  sustained  Government  commitment  to  a  market-oriented 
rural finance sector is a significant risk, as is the possibility of delays in 
implementation.  The  Government’s  repeated  commitment  in  several 
key  policy  and  strategy  documents  in  the  past  2  years  mitigates  this 
risk,  as  do  ongoing  policy  dialogue,  stakeholder  coordination,  and 
capacity-building support that is built into the program. 
 
APB  may  remain  vulnerable  to  loan  losses  as  it  undergoes  its 
restructuring.  Safeguards  against  poor  performance 
include 
(i) performance-based  recapitalization;  (ii)  strictly  enforced  adherence 
to  the  APB  governance  agreement  and  sanctions  for  noncompliance; 
(iii)  strengthened  supervisory  regime  for  APB;  (iv)  tightening  of  credit 
standards  and  more  rigorous  credit  appraisal  through  improved  credit 
policies  and  procedures  and  application  of  ICT  for  improving  risk 
management;  and  (v)  investment  in  capacity  building  for  adoption  of 
best practices.

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) two proposed 
loans  to  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  for  the  Rural  Finance  Sector 
Development Program (RFSDP), and (ii) a proposal to administer a grant from the Japan Fund 
for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) for catalyzing microfinance for the poor. The report also describes 
a  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  project  for  Program  Management  and  Building  Human 
Resource  Capacity  in  the  Agriculture  Promotion  Bank  (APB),  including  the  administration  by 
ADB of the portion of the TA to be financed by the Government of Denmark, and a proposal to 
administer  a  grant  from  the  Japan  Fund  for  Information  and  Communications  Technology

the proposed loans, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the 
TA and the administration of the Government of Denmark and JFICT grants.

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Sector Description and Performance  

 
A. 
 
2. 
The Macroeconomic Context. The Lao PDR’s human development index rank (135 out 
of  175)  is  among  the  lowest  in  Asia.  Annual  economic  growth  has  averaged  5.7%  in  recent 
years, contributing to a reduction in the poverty rate from 45% in 1992/93 to 39% in 1997/98 and 
to about 32% in 2002/03.1 However, growth has been unevenly distributed. The lowest income 
quintile accounted for only 8% of total consumption in 1997/98, compared with 9.3% in 1992/93. 
In contrast, the highest quintile accounted for 44.4% of total consumption in 1997/98, compared 
with 38.4% in 1992/93. During this period, the Gini coefficient rose from 28.6 to 35.7. While this 
coefficient  is  low  relative  to  other  countries  in  the  region,  its  rise  indicates  that  the  benefits  of 
economic  growth  accrued  more  to  the  non-poor  than  to  the  poor.  Correspondingly,  during  this 
period,  real  per  capita  consumption  in  the  rural  areas  increased  by  5.4%  per  year  while  urban 
consumption  increased  by  9%.  As  a  result,  poverty  also  declined  more  rapidly  in  urban  areas, 
leading  to  a  rising  disparity  between  urban  and  rural  incomes.  However,  results  from  the  Lao 
Expenditure  and  Consumption  Survey  (LECS)  III  indicate  a  reversal  in  this  trend—the  drop  in 
poverty between 1997/98 and 2002/03 has been largely attributed to the decline in the number of 
rural poor. In 1997, rural poverty was estimated as 50 % higher than in urban areas. As of 2003, 
the incidence of rural poverty was estimated as 30% more than urban poverty.2  
 
3. 
Economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  have  been  hindered  by  occasional  bouts  of 
macroeconomic instability. The Lao PDR began its transition to a market economy in 1986 with 
the adoption of the New Economic Mechanism, under which the Government pursued a number 
of  important  reforms,  such  as  (i)  redefining  and  limiting  the  role  of  the  state  in  allocating 
resources, (ii) liberalizing prices and trade, (iii) introducing business legislation, (iv) transferring 
agriculture  production  to  private  households,  (v)  privatizing  some  state-owned  enterprises,  and 
(vi) establishing a two-tiered banking system. The reforms had a strong impact on the economy, 
and growth averaged over 6% in the initial years of the transition. Beginning in 1997, following 
the  Asian  financial  crisis,  the  Government  pursued  an  expansionary  fiscal  policy  financed  by 
central bank credit. As a result, inflation increased to 130% in 1999, the kip depreciated sharply, 
and  losses  accumulated  in  the  banks  and  enterprises.  The  authorities  began  a  stabilization 
program  in  1999  and,  over  the  next  18  months,  re-established  a  stable  macroeconomic

 framework.  Since  2000,  the  Government’s  macroeconomic  management  has  been  generally 
successful,  although  the  tenuous  fiscal  situation  has  kept  the  macroeconomic  situation  fragile. 
From mid-2002 to May 2003, inflation again rose (to 18% by May 2003), and the exchange rate 
depreciated  due  to  fiscal  weaknesses.  However,  tighter  fiscal  control  has  stabilized  the 
exchange rate for the past year, and inflation declined to 6.5%.  
 
4. 
In this context, the National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES), adopted 
by the National Assembly in October 2003, emphasizes the promotion of sustainable, equitable 
growth to improve the quality of life and to eradicate basic poverty. NGPES stresses that socio-
economic development must be based on sound macroeconomic management and institutional 
strengthening  and  balanced  between  economic  growth,  sociocultural  development,  and 
environmental preservation. The long-term objective is to sustain economic growth at an average 
rate of about 7%, considered to be the necessary rate for tripling per- capita income by 2020 and 
enabling the Lao PDR to graduate from the list of least developed countries. Development of a 
sustainable,  market-oriented  rural  finance  sector  is  identified  as  a  key  element  to  support  the 
NGPES. 
 
5. 
Poverty  in  Rural  Areas.  The  rural  population comprises  72%  of  the  total  population  of 
5.5  million,  and  80%  of  the  workforce  are  engaged  in  agriculture.3  The  contribution  of  the 
agriculture  sector  to  the  national  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  is  51%,  while  in  the  northern 
region,  agriculture  accounts  for  more  than  70%  of  GDP.4  Annual  output  varies  because  the 
country  is  dependent  on  rain-fed  agriculture.  While  overall  the  country  is  self-sufficient  in  food, 
some remote areas still face seasonal food shortages. 
 
While rural poverty may have declined, some 90% of the country’s poor continue to live in 
6. 
rural  areas.  Poverty  is  more  prevalent  in  the  remoter  and  more  mountainous  areas,  where 
access  to  fertile  land,  basic  social  services,  transport,  and  communications  is  limited.5  The 
northern region has the highest incidence of poverty, estimated at 52.5% in 1997/98. Of the 72 
districts  designated  as  very  poor,  40  are  in  the  northern  region.  Two  northern  provinces, 
Oudomxay  and  Huaphanh,  have  a  poverty  incidence  of  over  70%,  and  there  are  28  districts 
nationally, all in remote rural areas, where poverty incidence is over 70%. Annually, some 90,000 
people  enter  the  labor  force,  mostly  in  rural  areas,  for  whom  employment  opportunities  are 
needed.6  Maintaining  high  growth  rates  in  the  rural  sector  will  be  critical  in  achieving  the 
Government’s development and poverty reduction goals.  
 
7. 
Demand for Rural Finance. The Government’s definitions of rural and microfinance are 
similar  to  those  of  ADB.  Per  the  Government’s  Policy  Statement  for  the  Development  of 
Sustainable Rural and Micro Finance Sector, issued by the Prime Minister’s Office in November 
2003,  microfinance  “means  the  provision  of  a  broad  range  of  financial  services,  such  as  cash 
based  credit,  deposits,  insurance,  etc.,  to  the  poor,  low-income  households,  and  their  micro-
enterprises,” and rural finance “means the provision of a broad range of financial services, such 
as cash based credit, deposits, insurance, etc, to people and enterprises located in rural areas.” 
In  the  context  of  the  Lao  PDR’s  predominantly  rural  and  agriculture-based  economy, 
microfinance will generally (though not exclusively) be a subset of rural finance.

agricultural  production,  livestock  raising,  nonfarm  income-generating  activities  (including  micro, 
small,  and  medium-size  agribusiness),  and  household  consumption;  and  for  secure  savings

Flatland  rain-fed  and  irrigated  farming  systems  are  found  close  to  the  Mekong 
River  and  its  tributaries.  In  these  areas,  cultivated  land  is  used  for  lowland  rice 
production in the wet season and for livestock grazing in the dry season.  
The  plateau  farming  system  is  found  on  the  Bolovens  plateau  (Attapeu, 
Champasack,  and  Sekong  provinces)  and  in  two  other  plateau  areas  in 
Khammuane  and  Xiengkhuang  provinces.  Under  this  system,  commercial  crops 
are increasingly produced, and cattle are grazed on the plains and in the forests.  
Upland  farming  systems  are  characterized  by  slash-and-burn  practices,  and  are 
dominated  by  a  single  wet  season  crop,  mainly  upland  rice.  Cattle,  pigs,  and 
poultry are raised under extensive husbandry systems.  
The  mountain  farming  system  operates  in  remote  villages.  The  system  is  also 
based on slash-and-burn cultivation of upland rice on mountain slopes, with little 
or  no  production  surplus.  A  variety  of  other  crops  are  incorporated  into  the 
system, and livestock are more intensively managed than other systems.  

 
9. 
Households practicing these four farming systems reported borrowing for agriculture and 
other  activities  that  are  prevalent  in  their  systems.  The  survey  found  that  48%  of  households 
borrowed from at least one source in the 12 months before the survey. Reported unmet demand 
was  also  high,  with  many  households  reporting  an  inability  to  borrow  sufficiently  for  common 
activities in their farming systems—unmet demand by rural households of KN32 trillion was four 
times  as  large  as  actual  borrowing  of  KN800  billion.  The  highest  level  of  reported  unmet 
demand–35%  of  households–occurred  in  remote  rural  areas,  followed  by  households  in 
provincial  capitals  (34%),  households  in  peri-urban  areas  (23%),  and  households  in  the  rural 
Mekong  area  (11%).7  Overall,  27%  of  households  reported  unmet  credit  demand  in  the  12 
months  before  the  survey.  The  most  commonly  cited  activities  for  which  financing  was 
inadequate were rice production, animal raising, trade, and transport. 
 
10. 
There is also a clear segmentation of the market by wealth level. Table 1 shows that the 
rural poor tend to rely on family, friends, and moneylenders more commonly than the less poor. 
Although only 7.7% of the richest rural households borrowed from a commercial bank in the last 
12 months, this still represents significantly greater access than that for the two poorest quartiles, 
of  whom  only  1.7%  and  1.4%,  respectively,  borrowed  from  a  commercial  bank.  This  pattern 
applies to APB also, with 5.2% of the richest quartile borrowing compared with only 1.0% of the 
poorest  quartile.  Additional  data  indicate  that  the  most  common  activities  of  the  two  poorest 
quartiles that faced unsatisfied demand for credit were agriculture and animal raising, while the 
two richest quartiles more commonly reported unsatisfied demand for credit to finance wholesale 
and retail trade.

There is also a strong demand for secure savings facilities that are easily accessible and 
retain their value. Across all wealth groups, the most valued characteristics of a savings vehicle 
were (i) ability to retain or increase in value, with 35% citing this as an important characteristic; 
(ii)  liquidity  (30%);  and  (iii)  safety  (16%).  However,  savings  mobilization  in  the  formal  sector  is 
low—less than 15% of all Lao households have a savings account in the formal sector, and over 
90%  of  savings  in  formal  financial  institutions  are  held  by  urban  clients.  Only  5.8%  of  rural 
households  surveyed  in  early  2004  held  any  savings  in  a  bank,  another  5.2%  held  savings  in 
semiformal  financial  institutions,  and  2.1%  held  savings  in  informal  rotating  savings  and  credit 
associations.  Less  than  one  third  of  cash  savings  and  only  about  2%  of  total  savings  in  rural 
areas  are  deposited  in  the  banking  system.  At  the  same  time,  98%  of  households  reported 
savings in the form of livestock, 35% in the form of housing materials such as lumber, and 38% 
in the form of precious metals and jewelry; the poorest quartile hold 93% of their savings in kind. 
Nonetheless,  50%  of  households  surveyed  reported  that  a  bank  would  be  their  first  or  second 
preference as a savings vehicle, indicating large unmet demand for formal savings services.  
 
12. 
Supply  of  Rural  Finance.  Despite  the  high  and  varied  demand,  the  financial  sector  in 
the Lao PDR has a low level of outreach in rural areas. APB is the only formal financial institution 
with  significant  outreach  and  service  history  in  rural  areas.  It  has  a  branch  in  each  of  the 
country’s 17 provinces, a branch covering Vientiane Municipality, and subservice units in 55 of 
the  country’s  141  districts.8  Per  its  records,  APB  provides  credit  and  savings  services  to  about 
120,000 (or 14%) of the country’s estimated 900,000 households. However, the survey of 1,189 
households done in early 2004 indicated that only 1.95% had borrowed from APB in the previous 
12 months, confirming that the bulk of APB’s current clients are urban. 
 
13. 
Since APB’s creation in 1993, its operations have concentrated on providing subsidized 
credit to producers of agricultural products (notably rice), livestock, and handicrafts. Its funding 
has been provided by national and local government budget allocations, the Bank of Lao PDR 
(BOL, the central bank), and international development agencies. As of 31 December 2003, APB 
had  60  such  funding  arrangements  that  financed  52%  of  its  loan  portfolio.  Major  aid-funded 
credit  lines  still  outstanding  have  come  from  ADB  ($7  million),  the  Government  of  Japan 
($2 million in equipment), International Fund for Agriculture Development ($500,000), European

14. 
In the semiformal sector, five initiatives that seek to provide microfinance services on a 
sustainable  basis  have  only  about  5,900  savers  and  4,600  borrowers―for  the  most  part  the 
savings are compulsory deposits that partially guarantee borrowers’ loans.  
 
15. 
In  addition  to  these  sustainably  focused  initiatives,  about  35  international  non-
government  organizations  (NGOs)  and  bilateral  development  agencies  have  supported  small-
scale  credit  initiatives  in  remote  areas,  largely  through  village  funds.  In  some  districts,  these 
village funds are significant providers of financial services, representing the only source of credit 
other than family and friends. About 8,000 households have access to loans from village-based 
funds. However, these funds have generally been an ancillary activity attached to projects with 
broader  development  goals  and  have  not  focused  on  the  development  of  a  sustainable 
microfinance  institution  (MFI).  They  often  become  nonoperational  after  project  support  ends.  A 
major role in the implementation of such projects has been played by the Lao Women’s Union 
(LWU).  
 
16. 
In  the  informal  sector,  family  and  friends  are  consistently  reported  to  be  the  primary 
source of credit by most households, and borrowing from moneylenders is less common. In the 
2004 rural finance survey, 25% of households reported borrowing from a friend or family member 
in  the  previous  12  months,  and  57%  reported  that  they  would  first  approach  a  friend  or  family 
member  if  they  needed  a  loan.  In  contrast,  1.95%  reported  borrowing  from  APB  and  19% 
reported  that  they  would  first  approach  APB  if  they  needed  a  loan.  Only  2.14%  reported 
borrowing  from  a  moneylender,  and  only  1.9%  reported  that  they  first  would  approach  a 
moneylender  if  they  needed  a  loan.  Appendix  1  gives  a  fuller  analysis  of  the  rural  and 
microfinance sector. 
 
B. 
 
17. 
A  dynamic  rural  economy  is  necessary  to  achieve  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction 
goals  and  requires  sustainable,  market-oriented  rural  and  microfinance  institutions  that  can 
intermediate  between  savers  and  borrowers,  efficiently  allocate  resources,  and  facilitate 
production  and  the  exchange  of  goods  and  services.  Lao  PDR’s  rural  finance  sector  faces 
significant  constraints  in  fulfilling  its  potential  to  contribute  to  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction. The Lao population in rural areas is highly dispersed, and limited infrastructure adds 
to  the  cost  of  financial  intermediation  and  inhibits  information  flows  for  lenders  and  borrowers. 
These factors combined with the small-scale nature of transactions pose serious challenges for 
developing  rural  finance.  Indeed,  it  is  estimated  that  20%  of  households  live  in  such  remote 
areas, with no road access at any time of the year, that it may be difficult to provide them with 
microfinance services on a sustainable basis. 
 
18. 
In the absence of access to formal sources of credit, the poor continue to rely on informal 
sources of finance, including landlords, merchants, moneylenders, relatives, and friends. Loans 
from friends and family are usually interest-free, but sometimes carry interest rates common to 
moneylenders.  Typical  interest  rates  charged  by  moneylenders,  merchants,  and  other  informal 
sources are 10% per month (120% per year) and can be as high as 40% per month. Alternative, 
affordable, and sustainable sources of rural financial services are therefore necessary to support 
economic growth and poverty reduction in the rural economy.  
 

Issues and Opportunities 

 

 Agriculture  Promotion  Bank.  The  Government's  policy  to  support  access  to  rural 
19. 
finance has been implemented primarily by APB, which was established as a policy bank in 1993 
and has acted as a channel for Government and aid funds and subsidies by carrying out policy 
lending  on  behalf  of  the  Government.9  APB’s  interest  rates  on  policy  loans  have  been 
determined  by  either  the  Government  or  agreements  with  aid  agencies  and  other  funding 
sources. Typically, they are below market rates, as low as 7% per year, and insufficient to cover 
APB’s  costs.  APB’s  ordinary  lending  is  funded  from  deposits,  with  lending  rates  closer  to 
commercial terms (e.g., 20% for crops and livestock, 24% for handicraft, 26% for small industry, 
30% for trade and services, and 34% for overdrafts). These rates are set by APB’s Board, but 
they are not based on APB’s actual risks. APB's outreach is limited because it depends on the 
limited  funding  available  from  the  Government  and  aid  agencies  and  because  its  policies, 
inefficient  and  subsidized  operations,  and  weak  financial  condition  prevent  it  from  mobilizing 
commercial  funding.  Institutionally,  APB  carries  out  financial  and  nonfinancial  activities  (for 
example,  distributing  fertilizer  and  equipment),  reflecting  its  mixed  mandate  as  a  financial 
institution  and  development  organ  of  the  state.  As  a  result,  its  operations  are  inefficient,  and 
management autonomy and responsibility are limited. 
 
20. 
Subsidized  interest  rates  and  the  common  practice  of  rolling  over  loans  have 
prevented  APB  from  developing  and  adopting  realistic  credit  risk  assessment  and  loan  pricing 
practices, and have contributed to a weak credit culture and high levels of non-performing loans 
(NPLs). Consequently, according to international accounting standards, APB has been operating 
at  a  significant  loss  since  it  was  established  in  1993.  However,  before  2002,  APB  had  never 
been  audited,  making  its  financial  situation  (and,  therefore,  costs  to  the  Government  budget) 
unclear.  APB’s  first  audit,  which  took  place  in  2002,  indicated  a  high  rate  of  NPLs10  as  of 
December  2001,  and  inadequate  provision  for  doubtful  debts.  APB’s  portfolio  regrading 
undertaken  as  of  31  December  2003  indicates  that  the  high  NPL  rate  is  driven  largely  by  its 
policy lending, which has an NPL rate that is 2.4 times higher than the NPL rate of its ordinary 
loan  portfolio.  APB  has  incurred  significant  losses  each  year  since  its  establishment, 
representing costs to the Government budget. Loans of about KN82.5 billion (35% of APB’s total 
portfolio)  needed  to  be  written  off  as  of  31  December  2003.  The  amount  comprised  KN59.4 
billion  in  policy  loans  (52%  of  the  policy  lending  portfolio)  and  KN23.2  billion  in  ordinary  loans 
(26% of the ordinary portfolio). Since APB’s establishment in 1993, about $1 million equivalent 
per year on average has been lost and losses have accelerated in recent years. Further analysis 
of APB’s financial performance and projections is in Appendix 1 and Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
21.  Market  reforms  in  APB  are  necessary  to  enable  it  to  increase  outreach  sustainably 
without  burdening  the  Government  budget.  Moreover,  international  and  Lao  experience 
demonstrate that the non-poor are the main beneficiaries of subsidized interest rates since they 
have  greater  access  and  can  absorb  larger  loans.  Over  half  of  APB’s  loan  portfolio  is 
concentrated in the two wealthiest areas of the country—Vientiane and Champasack. The 2004 
survey of 1,189 households indicated that 77% of APB’s borrowers in the sample were of above-
average wealth as measured by asset value; and 58% came from the provincial capital or peri-
urban  areas.  In  contrast,  the  poor  were  three  times  as  likely  to  borrow  from  a  moneylender. 
International experience has shown that when subsidized loans are not available, the poor are 
willing  to  pay  market  interest  rates,  and  they  tend  to  value  sustained  access  more  than  a  low 
interest  rate.  The  2004  survey  bears  this  out  for  the  Lao  PDR  too—46%  of  households  in  the 
poorest  quartile  cited  “confidence  that  a  loan  will  be  made”  as  an  important  characteristic  in 
choosing  where  to  apply  for  a  loan,  but  only  19%  cited  the  interest  rate  as  an  important

APB’s  legal  status  is  somewhat  ambiguous.  It  was  established  by  prime  ministerial 
22. 
decree no. 92/PM on 19 June 1993 as a development bank, with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) 
holding  its  shares.  Per  Article  5  of  this  decree,  “the  state  budget  encourages  reduced  lending 
rates and guarantees minimum prices of major agricultural products … so that farmers need not 
be concerned with the marketing of their production”. Per article 6, “BOL … shall implement the 
required  conditions  concerning  the  establishment  of  this  bank,  to  determine  its  organizational 
structure,  and  to  establish  regulations  governing  the  management  and  the  action  program  of 
APB, which will be submitted for approval of the Government.” Presidential decree no. 02/PR on 
Commercial  Banks,  22  March  2000,  appears  to  bring  APB  largely  under  its  provisions, 
superseding  the  1993  establishment  decree.  However,  the  wording  of  this  decree  can  be 
interpreted  to  leave  APB’s  status  as  a  “commercial”  or  “development”  bank  uncertain;  and  in 
effect, APB has continued to be treated as a development bank, separate from the other state-
owned commercial banks. As such, BOL has not conducted on-site supervision of APB and has 
not required APB to comply with prudential ratios or to submit standard reports and information 
for off-site supervision. APB has effectively gone unregulated and unsupervised by BOL since its 
establishment. 
 
23.  Microfinance Institutions and Initiatives. Microfinance is at an embryonic stage in the 
Lao  PDR.  The  combined  outreach  of  the  four  largest  initiatives  is  less  than  6,000.  APB’s 
operations  have  tended  to  distort  the  rural  finance  system  and  result  in  misallocation  of 
resources, low deposit mobilization, and crowding out of MFIs and other banks—further limiting 
outreach. They also create a climate of unrealistic expectations on the part of potential borrowers 
and central and local officials regarding the cost of credit, thus making it difficult for microfinance 
initiatives  to  charge  sustainable  interest  rates  even  in  areas  where  APB’s  outreach  is  limited. 
Village  revolving  funds  established  by  the  LWU  in  some  1,600  villages  (sometimes  with  the 
support  of  international  aid  agencies)  reinforce  these  expectations—in  general,  they  channel  a 
limited amount of subsidized credit to a few households, do not mobilize local resources, have 
low repayment rates, and are not sustainable. It is unknown how many are still operational. 
 
24. 
Projects  or  MFIs  that  attempt  to  charge  sustainable  interest  rates  are  typically 
discouraged or prevented from doing so by local officials. The lack of a clear legal and regulatory 
framework  for  microfinance  gives  MFI  practitioners  little  recourse  to  counter  interference  from 
such officials. This lack of a transparent framework and the consequent interference are cited by 
international  NGOs  and  other  potential  microfinance  investors  as  the  main  reason  for  not 
investing in the sector. Current regulations (regulation no. 02/SB of 15 November 1994 issued by

29. 
Lessons Learned. In addition to building on the recent achievements supported by the 
TA cluster, the program also incorporates lessons learned from previous assistance to the Lao 
PDR.14  Specifically,  it  emphasizes  the  need  to  ensure  a  sustainable,  positive  real  interest  rate 
policy in APB by eliminating interest rate subsidies. Such subsidies are a drain on the national 
budget  and  have  a  distorting  effect  on  markets  that  is  inconsistent  with  the  Government’s 
strategy to move toward an efficient market-oriented economy. The program, through a step-by-
step consensus-building approach initiated by the TA cluster, has also allowed for a longer lead 
time  for  reform  measures  that  are  dependent  on  legislation  or  regulatory  changes.  This 
participatory approach has built in the Government a strong sense of ownership for the program, 
while simultaneously coordinating support from various aid agencies, including IMF, World Bank, 
bilateral agencies, and international NGOs. Information on external assistance and coordination 
in  the  financial  sector  is  in  Appendix  2.  The  program  takes  into  consideration  existing  capacity 
constraints in the staffs of executing agencies and implementing agencies by incorporating TA to 
build  capacity  and  support  implementation,  and  targeting  TA  at  the  appropriate  technical  level. 
Importantly,  the  program  takes  into  account  the  unfavorable  experience  in  recapitalizing  the 
state-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCBs)  under  previous  programs  by  addressing  institutional 
weaknesses,  credit  policies  and  procedures,  management  autonomy,  and  workout  of  NPLs. 
Moreover, recapitalization of APB will be subject to strictly enforced performance criteria agreed 
upon by APB, BOL, MOF, and ADB.

a. 

Creating an Enabling Policy Framework for Public and Private 
Provision of Rural and Microfinance 

 
37. 
Throughout  2002  and  2003,  the  Government  carried  out  an  extensive  participatory 
process with key stakeholders to develop an enabling national policy on rural and microfinance. 
This policy replaces the over reliance on subsidized, directed credit channeled through APB and 
encourages  the  establishment  and  operation  of  alternative  sources  of  rural  finance,  including 
microfinance. The process resulted in the Prime Minister’s Office’s (PMO’s) endorsement of the 
Policy  Statement  for  the  Development  of  Sustainable  Rural  and  Micro  Finance  Sector  in 
November  2003.  The  Policy  Statement  presents  a  vision  that  (i)  the  sector  will  expand 
significantly; (ii) the sector will include a diversity of independent MFIs, including private and/or 
public institutions with access to national and international public and private investors, including 
international  donors  and  development  partners;  (iii)  the  sector  will  become  sustainable,  and 
interest  rates  will  be  set  by  MFIs’  management  based  on  full  cost  recovery,  profitability,  and 
market  demand;  and  (iv)  the  environment  will  ensure  security  for  depositors,  including 
implementation  of  an  appropriate  legal  and  regulatory  framework  and  strengthening  of 
supervision of deposit-taking MFIs. 
 
The Government is following up the development of the Policy Statement with a strategy 
38. 
and action plan for its implementation. The Government’s RMFC will initiate a process of regular 
consultations  with  key  stakeholders  to  conduct  policy  dialogue  and  to  review  progress  in 

 

 implementing  the  Policy  Statement  and  strategy.  In  recognition  of  the  fact  that  rural  and 
microfinance  is  an  integral  part  of  the  overall  financial  sector,  the  Government  will  incorporate 
rural finance in the financial sector strategy that will be prepared by June 2007. As a result, rural 
and microfinance development will shift from an ad hoc project approach to a coherent national 
strategy that provides short-, medium-, and long-term direction, and has been and will continue 
to  be  participatory  in  its  formulation,  formalization,  and  implementation.  This  formal  foundation 
will  create  an  enabling  environment  for  deepening  the  rural  and  microfinance  sector  and  will 
encourage domestic private participation in the sector. 
 

b. 

Creating a Sound Prudential Regulatory and Supervisory 
Environment for Public and Private Rural and Microfinance 
Institutions 

 
39. 
Because of APB’s historical role as a policy bank, it has effectively gone unsupervised by 
BOL.  With  its  transformation  into  a  market-oriented  rural  finance  institution,  APB  will  now  be 
recognized and  treated  as  an  SOCB  and  will  therefore  be  subject  to  the  prudential  regulations 
and supervisory regime applicable to SOCBs. BOL will issue instructions to APB to comply with 
prudential  regulations  on  loan  classification  and  provisioning  (including  a  category  for  special 
mention  loans)  starting  October  2005  and  to  comply  with  all  prudential  regulations  other  than 
capital adequacy and minimum capital requirements by December 2005. BOL will develop and 
implement  a  supervisory  regime  of  monthly  off-site  and  semiannual  on-site  inspection  of  APB. 
APB will undergo annual external audits according to international financial reporting standards 
(IFRS)  and,  beginning  in  2006,  will  publish  its  IFRS  financial  statements.  To  ensure  that  APB, 
under  its  status  as  an  SOCB,  can  continue  to  conduct  microfinance  operations  through  group-
lending arrangements, Article 65 of the Commercial Bank Decree will be amended to clarify that 
collateral requirements for bank loans will abide by the rules and loan agreements set out by the 
banks.16 
 
The  lack  of  transparent  and  enabling  regulations  for  microfinance  has  been  a  major 
40. 
reason  for  the  lack  of  investment  in  MFIs  and  has  resulted  in  arbitrary  interference  in  MFI 
operations,  rendering  sustainability  difficult.  To  create  an  enabling  legal,  regulatory,  and 
supervisory  framework  for  microfinance,  BOL  will  adopt  and  implement  regulations,  bylaws, 
guidelines,  a  chart  of  accounts,  and  accounting  standards  for  MFIs  based  on  best  practice 
principles. The regulations will, for the first time in the Lao PDR, allow for multiple MFI models 
and products with minimum starting regulations, interest rate autonomy, and private ownership.

withdrawal; or (ii) if the loan proceeds finance items to be imported, the value of eligible imports 
in the immediately preceding one-year period will be equal to or greater than the amount of the 
requested withdrawal plus all other amounts expected to be withdrawn during the period.

C. 
 

The Project Loan 

1. 

Objectives 

 
59. 
The  project  loan’s  objective  is  to  promote  a  sustainable  and  market-oriented  rural  and 
microfinance  sector.  It  will  contribute  to  achievement  of  this  objective  by  assisting  the 
Government  to  (i)  build  BOL’s  MFI  supervision  capacity,  (ii)  support  APB  to  complete  the 
capacity building components of the APB Restructuring Plan begun under ADB TA cluster 3413 
(footnote 11), and (iii) upgrade APB’s ICT system. 
 

2. 

Components and Outputs 

a. 

Building BOL’s MFI Supervision Capacity 

 
BOL’s Supervision Department is responsible for licensing, regulating, and supervising all

carries out off-site monitoring and on-site inspection. BOL has been unable to effectively enforce 
bank  regulations  because  it  has  had  an  inadequate  number  of  supervisors  and  inadequate 
information for proper supervision. BOL recently began enforcing prudential regulations for state-
owned  banks  and,  with  assistance  from  IMF,  is  increasing  staff  and  putting  in  place  new 
procedures that will strengthen its capacity to supervise commercial banks. BOL recently created

a  microfinance  supervision  division,  with  4  staff  members  and  a  plan  to  expand  to  13  staff

b. 

Capacity Building Under APB’s Restructuring Plan 

 
61. 
The  project  loan  will  finance  the  engagement  of  an  international  banking  advisor  (IBA) 
and  two  domestic  administrator/banking  assistants  (ABAs)  to  assist  APB  to  complete  the 
restructuring program in accordance with the APB Governance Agreement. The IBA and ABAs 
will assist to review, revise, develop, implement, and monitor modern banking policies, systems, 
and  procedures  that  will  allow  APB  management  to  make  commercially  oriented  banking 
decisions  in  the  best  interests  of  APB.  The  IBA  and  ABAs  will  place  special  emphasis  on 
improved  risk  management,  NPL  resolution,  and  credit  risks,  policies,  and  procedures  to  stop 
loss-making activities. In carrying out his/her specific duties, the IBA will coach and train APB’s 
directors, management, and staff to build capacity in APB. 
 
62. 
APB  will  also  receive  specialized  assistance  to  review  its  accounting  policies  and 
procedures.  It  will  modify  and  document  in  manuals  its  policies  and  procedures  in  accordance 
with the detailed recommendations of the diagnostic review carried out under subproject 2 of the 
TA  cluster  and  the  management  letters  from  its  recent  financial  audits.  APB  will  revise  and 
document  its  accounting  standards  and  amend  them  to  include  (i)  accounting  on  an  accruals 
basis,  (ii)  identifying  and  transferring  NPLs  to  designated  overdue  ledger  accounts  on  a  timely 
basis, (iii) writing off bad debts, (iv) adjusting reserves to reflect the net asset position, (v) making 
provisions on guarantees and commitments for potential losses similar to any other extension of 
credit, (vi) depreciating fixed assets over their estimated useful lives, (vii) valuing inventories at 
the lower of cost and net realizable value, (viii) undertaking periodic stock counts and reconciling 
these with accounting records, (ix) investigating discrepancies in stock count reconciliation, and 
(x) adopting full liability accounting for income taxes and deferred taxation.  
 

c. 

Upgrading APB’s ICT Systems 

 
63. 
A review of APB’s current ICT system under ADB TA 3413 indicates that it needs to be 
replaced. This was confirmed by the ICT Strategy for the Lao Banking Sector prepared by BOL, 
with  the  assistance  of  the  European  Union.  These  reviews  found  that  APB’s  current  ICT 
environment  does  not  adequately  provide  the  systems  needed  in  a  modern  bank.  Specifically, 
(i) there is a lack of vision and strategy for ICT development, and consequently no effective plan 
or  budget  provision;  (ii)  the  mandate  of  the  ICT  unit  is  not  clear  in  relation  to  its  strategic  and 
planning  functions;  (iii)  the  systems  currently  in  use  at  APB  are  unable  to  provide  adequate 
customer  information,  making  risk  management  and  performance  assessment  difficult;  (iv)  the 
current system does not give management sufficient information on the performance of products 
and  bank  units,  so  new  banking  products  and  services  can  be  developed  only  when  a 
comprehensive  and  integrated  core  banking  system  is  in  place;  (v)  APB’s  ICT  staff  capacity  is 
inadequate  for  APB’s  current  and  future  needs;  (vi)  ICT  policy  and  procedures  are  not 
documented and not enforceable; (vii) ICT security is weak and there is no business continuity or 
disaster recovery plan; (viii) software in many instances is not licensed and is thus unsupported; 
(ix) the current system is decentralized and has inadequate treasury capabilities; (x) much of the 
current  MIS  is  manual  and  prone  to  error;  and  (xi)  connectivity  between  branches  is  weak  or 
nonexistent, with reports and data often physically ferried from subservice units to branches and 

 

 from  branches  to  head  office.  Additionally,  shortcomings  in  the  management  reporting  system 
make  it  of  limited  use  for  management  decision  making:  the  capacity  of  present  software  to 
generate reports is inadequate for management reporting; current reports are not differentiated 
by  user  or  management  level;  and  the  reporting  system  does  not  measure  bank  performance. 
Moreover, because APB has gone effectively unsupervised, the current system is inadequate to 
meet  BOL  requirements  under  the  new  supervision  regime,  which  will  require  that  APB  be 
treated as a commercial bank subject to full prudential supervision by BOL.

Benefits

89.

1. 

Impact  of  Creating  an  Enabling  Policy  Framework  for  Public  and  Private 
Provision of Rural and Microfinance 

 
93. 
The  program  will  for  the  first  time  create  a  formal  national  policy  framework  for  the 
development of rural and microfinance in the Lao PDR. This will move the sector’s development 
away from an ad hoc project approach toward a coherent national strategy that provides short-, 
medium- and long-term direction, has been participatory in its formulation and formalization, and 
will  remain  participatory  in  its  implementation.  This  formal  foundation  will  create  an  enabling 
environment for the deepening of the rural and microfinance sector and will encourage domestic 
private participation in the sector. 
 

2. 

Impact  of  Creating  a  Sound  Prudential  Regulatory  and  Supervisory 
Environment for Public and Private Rural and Microfinance Institutions 

 
A  sound  prudential  regulatory  and  supervisory  environment  will  create  greater 
94. 
transparency  in  the  financial  sector  generally  and  in  APB  and  MFIs  in  particular.  Creating 
transparency  in  APB’s  financial  affairs  will  improve  APB’s  overall  governance,  planning, 
operations, and  risk  management.  Ensuring  that  APB  is  properly  regulated  and  supervised  will 
provide  added  protection  to  APB’s  depositors  and  build  confidence  in  APB  as  a  deposit-taking 
institution, allowing it to grow in a market-oriented way in a competitive environment. Regulating 
MFIs will, for the first time in the Lao PDR, provide a full legal basis for the establishment and 
growth  of  privately  owned  MFIs.  These  measures  together  with  the  development  of  MFI 
supervisory capacity in BOL will remove the present legal and regulatory uncertainties that have 
been cited as the major reason for the lack of investment in the sector. Introducing the new legal 
and  regulatory  regime  will  create  the  opportunity  for  financial  intermediation  in  the  MFI  sector. 
Collectively these measures will enhance the safety and soundness of the financial sector. 
 

3. 

Impact  of  Transforming  APB  into  a  Financially  Self-Sustainable,  Market-
Oriented Rural Finance Institution  

 
The  transformation  of  APB  from  a  bank  that  acts  as  a  channel  for  loss-making  policy 
95. 
lending into a market-oriented bank that operates on a commercial basis will result in extending 
APB’s  outreach  as  it  expands  its  deposit-based  business  and  relies  less  on  the  resource-
constrained  Government  budget.  It  will  also  (i)  improve  efficiency  in  APB’s  operations  as  it 
comes under pressure to compete for resources; (ii) strengthen APB’s management autonomy; 
and  (iii)  improve  APB’s  currently  weak  credit  culture,  reduce  NPL  levels,  reduce  losses,  and 
hence  reduce  the  fiscal  burden  that  APB  places  on  the  Government.  Based  on  historic 

 

 performance, there will be fiscal savings of about $1 million per year; with losses accelerating in 
recent  years,  the  likely  impact  will  be  significantly  more  than  $1  million  per  year  in  the  future. 
APB’s  transformation  will  also  remove  some  of  the  distortionary  impacts  created  by  its 
subsidized  lending  operations:  low  deposit  mobilization,  crowding  out  of  MFIs  and  other  banks 
from  areas  where  its  subsidized  lending  programs  have  operated,  and  unrealistic  expectations 
regarding sustainable interest rates.

Rural and Microfinance

5. 

Social and Poverty Impacts 

 
The  RFSDP  is  expected  to  have  a  positive  social  impact  by  strengthening  the  rural 
97. 
finance  sector  and  promoting  sustainable  delivery  of  financial  services  in  rural  areas.  The 
improved  policy  and  regulatory  environment  supporting  rural  and  microfinance  institutions  will 
promote  the  establishment  and  operation  of  sustainable  microfinance  and  other  rural  financial 
institutions,  including  those  established  by  the  private  sector  and  international  development 
agencies.  These  institutions  will  provide  the  rural  poor  with  alternative  and  more  affordable 
options compared with informal sources, which typically charge interest rates of 10% per month 
or  higher.  The  RFSDP  will  foster  demand-driven,  sustainable  rural  financial  services. 
International  experience  shows  that  the  poor  are  willing  to pay  market  interest  rates  and  value 
sustained  access  more  than  a  subsidized  interest  rate.  Developing  a  market-oriented  rural 
financial system is therefore the best way to provide the poor with access to affordable financial 
services. Sustained access to financial services will enable the rural poor to (i) invest in, and take 
advantage  of,  opportunities  in  farm  and  nonfarm  income-generating  activities;  (ii)  finance 
household  emergencies  and  consumption;  and  (iii)  accumulate  savings  in  secure  deposit 
facilities. The MFF, which will pilot and promote best-practice MFIs serving a diverse population, 
will  give  preference  to  supporting  sustainable  microfinance  initiatives  that  benefit  women  and 
ethnic  groups.  The  RFSDP  is  in  line  with  the  NGPES,  approved  by  the  National  Assembly  in 
October  2003,  which  identifies  access  to  rural  finance  as  critical  to  reducing  poverty  and 
promoting economic growth.  
 
Restructuring  APB  into  a  financially  self-sustainable,  market-oriented  rural  finance 
98. 
institution will have both direct and indirect positive social benefits. Directly, APB’s transformation 
will  enable  it  to  increase  outreach  and  contribute  to  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  in 
the  Lao  PDR.  International  and  Lao  experience  have  shown  that  the  non-poor  are  the  primary 
beneficiaries of subsidized credit because they have better access and can absorb larger loans 
and,  therefore,  larger  subsidies.  APB’s  nonsubsidized,  demand-driven  expansion  is  therefore 
expected  to  benefit  the  poor  disproportionately.  Indirectly,  phasing  out  directed  lending  and 
interest rate subsidies from APB will free up scarce resources in the Government budget, which 
can contribute to better-targeted poverty interventions and reductions in the Government deficit, 
thus contributing to macroeconomic stability. If some residual policy lending is shifted to an on-
budget  nonbanking  mechanism,  the  enhanced  transparency  will  allow  policy  makers  to  better 
assess the costs and benefits of such lending.

Environmental Impacts 

Risks 

 
100.  A review of the policy interventions under the RFSDP indicates that they will not have any 
direct adverse environmental impact. The appraisal of potential income-generating activities that 
may  be  funded  through  APB  or  the  MFIs  receiving  assistance  from  MFF  indicates  that  these 
farm and nonfarm activities are not likely to result in significant environmental impact. To ensure 
that  no  adverse  impact  results  at  the  micro  level,  APB  and  MFIs  will  be  required  to  adhere  to 
sound  environmental  lending  practices  and  ensure  that  their  lending  operations  are  consistent 
with  existing  environmental  laws  and  regulations.  For  this  purpose,  training  on  sound 
environmental lending practices is incorporated in RFSDP activities. The environmental impacts 
of policy intervention are reviewed in Supplementary Appendix A.  
 
C. 
 
101.  The  successful  implementation  and  impact  of  the  RFSDP  will  depend  on  several 
assumptions  that  are  subject  to  varying  degrees  of  risk.  Mitigating  measures  have  been  put  in 
place where appropriate and possible. 
 
102.  Political  Commitment  to  Reform,  and  Timely  Implementation  of  Reforms.  The  lack 
of  sustained  Government  commitment  to  a  market-oriented  rural  finance  sector  is  a  significant 
risk, as is the possibility of implementation delays. However, the Government has reiterated its 
commitment on several occasions and in several key policy and strategy documents in the past 
3  years  –  the  Policy  Statement  on  Development  of  a  Sustainable  Rural  and  Micro  Finance 
Sector  (endorsed  by  PMO  in  November  2003),  the  National  Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication 
Strategy  (endorsed  by  the  National  Assembly  in  October  2003),  and  the  Strategy  and  Action 
Plan to Develop Sustainable Rural and Microfinance (in final draft stage and to be issued by BOL 
as a first-tranche RFSDP policy action). In addition, the design process has included extensive 
awareness  creation  and  consultation  with  stakeholders,  supported  by  ADB  TA  3413  (footnote 
12)  since  October  2000,  including  (i)  policy  awareness  workshops  and  study  tours  for  senior 
policy  makers,  and  the  Government’s  agreement  to  reform  recommendations  in  the  ensuing 
Rural  and  Microfinance  Policy  Issues  Paper;  (ii)  an  in-depth  diagnostic  study  of  APB  and  the 
Government’s  agreement  with  its  findings;  (iii)  approval  by  the  Government  of  the  feasibility 
study and the business plans for three member-owned pilot SCUs, and the subsequent issuance 
of licenses for the pilot SCUs; (iv) the Government’s approval and the APB Board’s adoption of 
the  APB  restructuring  plan  and  new  market-oriented  corporate  mission  for  APB;  (v)  the 
Government’s  agreement  to  phase  out  interest  rate  subsidies  and  directed  lending  from  APB; 
and  (vi)  the  Government’s  approval  of  new,  best  practice  regulations  for  SCUs  and  MFIs. 
Throughout this 3-year process, there has been a continuous and progressive dialogue between 
the  Government,  ADB,  and  other  stakeholders  in  the  sector,  including  PMO,  BOL,  APB,  MOF, 
Committee  for  Planning  and  Cooperation,  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF), 

 

 commercial  banks,  microfinance  practitioners,  mass  organizations,  NGOs,  and  other  agencies 
such  as  the  World  Bank  and  IMF.  Implementation  will  involve  the  same  stakeholders  and  will 
engage  them  through  a  formal  consultative  framework.  Effective  policy  dialogue,  stakeholder 
coordination,  and  capacity-building  support  through  project  components  and  the  TA  are 
safeguards for smooth implementation of policy reforms. Public awareness of the benefits from 
the reforms will further mitigate the possible risk of delays in policy reforms. To expedite reforms, 
the RFSDP supports institutional strengthening and performance-based recapitalization for APB. 
 
103.  Fiscal Management. The estimated cost of implementing the Program is $19.2 million. 
The  amount  represents  the  direct  costs  of  policy  reforms  and  related  investments,  including 
(i) creating an enabling policy framework ($1.5 million); (ii) creating a sound prudential regulatory 
and  supervisory  environment  that  includes  BOL  strengthening  ($1.6  million);  (iii)  creating  a 
financially  self-sustainable,  market-oriented  APB,  including  institutional  strengthening,  ICT 
upgrade, and recapitalization ($13.6 million, of which $8.1 million represents recapitalization);22 
and  (iv)  creating  a  supportive  nonprudential  regulatory  environment  ($0.2  million).  This  cost 
potentially  represents  a  burden  on  budgetary  resources  and  management  capacity  of  the 
Government. However, a number of mitigating measures have been put in place to reduce this 
risk. In terms of budgetary resources, grant cofinancing amounting to $6.5 million from  various 
sources  has  been  mobilized  to  assist  in  financing  the  program.23  The  Government  will  finance 
the remaining $12.7 million, of which $10 million will be covered by the ADB program and project 
loans.  Much  of  the  remaining  $2.7  million  takes  the  form  of  in-kind  contributions  from  the 
Government, such as staff time.

1. 
The  rural  and  microfinance  sector  in  Lao  PDR  is  at  an  embryonic  stage.  The  principle 
provider of rural financial services is the state-owned Agriculture Promotion Bank (APB), which 
was  created  in  1993  as  a  policy  bank  to  deliver  subsidized  credit  to  the  agriculture  sector.  Its 
outreach  has  been  limited  to  about  15%  of  the  population  because  it  depends  on  the  limited 
funding  available  from  the  Government  and  donors  and  because  its  policies,  inefficient  and 
subsidized  operations,  and  weak  financial  condition  prevent  it  from  mobilizing  commercial 
funding. Very few microfinance institutions exist because of a historically unfavorable policy and 
regulatory  environment  as  well  as  high  transactions  costs  due  to  a  dispersed  population  and 
poor infrastructure. 
 
Rural  Economy.  The  population  of  Lao  PDR  is  estimated  at  5.5  million.  The  rural 
2.

the  population  is  growing  at  about  2.3%  per  year,  but  rural  to  urban  migration  has  resulted  in 
urban population growth of about 4.7% per year and rural population growth of about 1.8% per 
year.1

The contribution of the agricultural sector to GDP was 51% in 2002. Crops contributed 
30%, livestock and fisheries 17%, and forestry 4% of total GDP. Agricultural GDP grew by an

farming systems. Flatland rain-fed and irrigated farming systems are found close to the Mekong 
River and its tributaries. In these areas, cultivated land is used for lowland rice production in the 
wet  season  and  for  livestock  grazing  in  the  dry  season.  Upland  farming  systems  are 
characterized  by  slash  and  burn  practices,  and  are  dominated  by  a  single  wet  season  crop, 
mainly upland rice, but including maize in some areas. The gathering of forest products provides 
supplementary  food  and  firewood.  Cattle,  pigs,  and  poultry  are  raised  under  extensive 
husbandry  systems.  The  plateau

villages. The system is based on slash and burn cultivation of upland rice on mountain slopes

There  are  significant  opportunities  for  agricultural  and  rural  enterprise  development. 
Lao PDR  lies  at  the  center  of  a  rapidly  expanding  regional  economy  that  offers  a  regional 
market  with  some  200  million  people.  Given  its  resource  base,  location,  and  potential  cost 
advantages, the agricultural sector is well placed to benefit from growing regional prosperity and 
the  increasing  demand  for  food  and  other  agricultural  products  in  Lao PDR  and  adjoining 
countries.  
 
6. 
Recent  research  that  examined  competitive  advantage  with  neighboring  countries  of 
selected  agricultural  crops  (rice,  maize,  soybean,  coffee,  and  cotton)  indicates  that  with  the 
backing  of  research  and  efficiently  run  agricultural  support  services,  there  is  a  potential  for 
Lao PDR  to  compete  advantageously  with  its  neighboring  countries  in  the  production  of  these 
commodities. 5 Maize and soybean have export potential for animal feed, and there is scope for 
expansion of coffee exports. Cotton can substitute for imports used in the textile sector, one of 
Lao PDR’s main export earning industries. Fruit and vegetable production can be expanded to 
meet  domestic  demand  and  for  export  to  Thailand.6  The  demand  for  meat  in  the  domestic 
market  and  neighboring  countries  is  likely  to  continue  to  increase  in  the  foreseeable  future. 
Lao PDR has a competitive advantage in supplying cattle and buffalo to Thailand. Pilot projects 
have shown that commercial fish farming can result in yields of up to 500 kilograms per hectare. 
Integrating fisheries with livestock production has potential to increase this further. In addition to 
timber,  forests  yield  non-timber  forest  products  (NTFPs)  that  can  be  used  for  subsistence 
purposes  or  to  enhance  the  cash  incomes  of  rural  households.  Some  of  these  products  also 
provide  cash  income.  Other  traditional  forms  of  income  generating  activities  in  the  uplands 
include  handicraft  and  basketry  made  from  bamboo  and  rattan.  Products  include  winnowing 
baskets,  many  types  of  carrying  baskets,  mats,  and  small  tables.  Handicraft  and  embroidery 
products  include  buttons,  hair  ornaments,  and  necklaces  that  form  part  of  traditional  dress. 
There is also a strong tradition of weaving in the lowlands. Other activities include metalworking 
for tools production, especially knives, machetes, and spades.

Commercial Banking Sector. The financial sector of the Lao PDR remains shallow with 
limited  financial  intermediation  and  without  significant  outreach.  The  low  level  of  monetization 
throughout the population has kept the Lao PDR at one of the lowest levels of financial depth in 
the world. The sector consists exclusively of banks. There is one monopoly insurance company,

a small part of the population and those services delivered, with few exceptions, are not being 
provided on a sustainable or efficient basis.

10. 
BCEL began its operations in 1976. In 1989, it augmented its international business, and 
started  to  develop  its  branch  network.  It  now  has  seven  branches  including  the  head  office  in 
Vientiane.  Its  products  include  a  high  level  of  fee  income  from  trade  financing  and  foreign 
exchange transactions and its clients are generally the larger enterprises in the Lao PDR. BCEL 
dominates  the  market  with  about  four  tenths  of  total  banking  assets.  LDB  is  the  result  of  the 
merger in 2002 of Lao May Bank and Lane Xang Bank. It has a branch in each of the country’s 
17  provinces,  and  its  clients  are  primarily  small-  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  and 
personal banking customers, including housing loan borrowers. 
 
11. 
In addition to the SOCBs, there are three joint-venture commercial banks (JVCBs): Joint 
Development  Bank  (JDB),  Lao-Viet  Bank  (LVB),  and  Vientiane  Commercial  Bank  (VCB).  The 
JVCBs mainly service customers in the country’s principal cities. JDB was established in 1989. 
LVB started operations in 1999, with BCEL and Vietnam Development Bank as its joint owners. 
VCB  began  operating  in  1995.  A  third  banking  category  consists  of  six  foreign  commercial 
banks (FCBs), each operating a single branch office in Vientiane, and one other UK bank with a 
representative office in Vientiane—Standard Chartered Bank. The six FCBs are principally Thai 
commercial  banks—Bangkok  Bank,  Krung  Thai  Bank,  Siam  Commercial  Bank,  Bank  of 
Ayudhya,  and  Thai  Military  Bank—and  one  Malaysian  bank,  namely  Public  Bank.  The  FCBs 
service their home country clients who have operations in the Lao PDR. 
 
12. 
Agriculture  Promotion  Bank.  The  Government's  policy  to  support  access  to  rural 
finance  has  been  implemented  primarily  by  APB,  which  was  established  as  a  policy  bank  in 
1993  and  has  acted  as  a  channel  for  Government  and  donor  funds  and  subsidies by carrying 
out  policy  lending  on  behalf  of  the  Government.7  APB’s  interest  rates  have  been  determined 
either  by  the  Government  or  by  agreements  with  donors.  Typically,  these  are  below  market 
rates and insufficient to cover APB’s costs. APB’s ordinary lending is funded from deposits, with 
lending rates closer to commercial terms (e.g., 20% for crops and livestock; 24% for handicraft; 
26% for small industry; 30% for trade and services; and 34% for overdrafts). These rates are set 
by APB’s Board, but they reflect rates elsewhere in the state sector and are not based on APB’s 
actual risks.  
 
13. 
APB’s  activities  extend  to  about  6,000  villages.  APB  has  a  total  of  129,493  borrowers, 
comprising 123,306  group  members  in  13,342 groups  with  an  average  9  members  per  group; 
and  6,187  individual  borrowers.  APB  currently  reaches  about  14%  of  Lao  households.  APB's 
outreach  is  limited  because  it  depends  on  the  limited  funding  available  from  the  Government 
and donors and because its policies, inefficient and subsidized operations, and weak financial 
condition prevent it from mobilizing commercial funding. Institutionally, APB carries out financial 
and  non-financial  activities  (for  example:  distributing  fertilizer  and  equipment),  reflecting  its

Subsidized interest rates and the common practice of rolling over loans have prevented 
APB  from  developing  and  adopting  realistic  credit  risk  assessment  and  loan  pricing  practices.

KN59.4 billion in policy loans (52% of the policy lending portfolio) and KN23.2 billion in ordinary

15.  Microfinance  Institutions  and  Initiatives.  Microfinance  is  at  a  nascent  stage  in  Lao 
PDR. The combined outreach of the four largest initiatives is less than 6,000. APB’s operations 
have  tended  to  distort  the  rural  finance  system  and  result  in  misallocation  of  resources,  low 
deposit mobilization, and crowding out of MFIs and other banks, further limiting outreach. They 
also create a climate of unrealistic expectations on the part of potential borrowers and central 
and  local  officials  regarding  the  cost  of  credit,  making  it  difficult  for  microfinance  initiatives  to 
charge  sustainable  interest  rates  even  in  areas  where  APB’s  outreach  is  limited.  Village 
revolving funds established by the LWU in some 1,600 villages (sometimes with the support of 
international donors) reinforce these expectations—in general, they channel a limited amount of 
subsidized  credit  to  a  few  households,  do  not  mobilize  local  resources,  have  low  repayment 
rates, and are not sustainable. It is unknown how many are still operational. An indicative list of 
microfinance initiatives is included in Appendix 11. 
 
16. 
Projects  or  MFIs  that  attempt  to  charge  sustainable  interest  rates  are  typically 
discouraged  or  prevented  from  doing  so  by  local  officials.  The  lack  of  a  clear  legal  and 
regulatory  framework  for  microfinance  gives  MFI  practitioners  little  recourse  to  counter 
interference from officials. This lack of a transparent framework and the consequent interference 
is cited by international NGOs and other potential microfinance investors as the main reason for 
not  investing  in  the  sector.  Current  regulations  cover  only  credit  cooperatives  (regulation  no. 
02/SB of 15 November 1994 issued by BOL) and provide limited or no guidance on operational 
rules  of  governance,  conflicts  of  interest,  auditing  requirements  (external  and  internal), 
prudential discipline, reporting requirements, sanctions, and experience or qualification of board 
members.  Commensurate  with  the  lack  of  a  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  microfinance, 
BOL has no experience and limited capacity to supervise MFIs. As a result of these constraints, 
very  few  MFIs  operate  in  the  country.  Most  microfinance  is  delivered  through  one-off  projects

carried  out  in  2000–2001,  built  awareness  of  rural  finance  issues,  including  international 
experience  and  best  practice,  through  a  series  of  workshops  and  study  tours  and  prepared  a 
“Policy  and  Issues  Paper”  that  identified  weaknesses  in  the  institutional,  policy,  legal,  and 
regulatory framework. Step by step, it has been recognized that an improved policy environment 
for rural and microfinance is needed, and that market reforms in APB are necessary to enable it 
to  increase  outreach  sustainably  without  burdening  the  government  budget.  International  and 
Lao experience demonstrates that the non-poor are the main beneficiaries of subsidized interest 
rates  since  they  have  greater  access  and  can  absorb  larger  loans.  Over  half  of  APB’s  loan 
portfolio is concentrated in the two wealthiest areas of the country—Vientiane and Champasak 
International experience has shown that when subsidized loans are not available, the poor are 
willing  to  pay  market  interest  rates,  and  they  tend  to  value  sustained  access  more  than  a  low 
interest rate. Therefore, developing a market-oriented rural financial system is the best way to 
provide the poor with access to affordable financial services. 
 
23. 
To  begin  reforming  APB,  subproject  2  (May–December  2002)  conducted  a  diagnostic 
review  and  financial  audit  of  APB.  Based  on  the  findings,  an  APB  Restructuring  Plan  was 
prepared,  which  addresses  weaknesses  in  APB's  policies  and  procedures  in  many  areas, 
including governance, planning, organizational structure, pricing, credit, products and services, 
information  and  communications  technology  (ICT),  risk  management,  and  accounting.  In 
November  2002,  the  Government  adopted  a  new  corporate  vision  for  APB  to  "operate  in  a 
market-oriented,  financially  self-sustainable  way  to  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  and  the 
country's  economic  growth  and  prosperity."  Implementation  of  the  first  phase  of  the  APB 
Restructuring Plan began in March 2003 under subproject 5. Importantly, this includes a plan to 
phase policy lending out of APB by the end of 2007 and to shift residual policy lending, if any, to 
a transparent, non-banking mechanism on the Government budget. 
 
24.  While  the  capacity  of  APB  is  being  developed  through  its  restructuring  program, 
institutional mechanisms involving the private sector are also being promoted under subproject 
3  of  the  TA  cluster,  begun  in  March  2003,  which  established  three  pilot  SCUs  in  areas  with 
strong  market  linkages.  These  SCUs  are  member-owned  and  managed,  with  full  autonomy  in 
their management, hiring procedures, interest rates, access to capital, and choice of products, 
clientele, and geographical coverage.  
 
25. 
In addition, the Government's Rural and Microfinance Committee (RMFC), with support 
from  ADB,  Concern  Worldwide,  the  Financial  Sector  Reform  and  Strengthening  Initiative 
(FIRST),  and  the  World  Bank,  prepared  an  official  vision  and  policy  statement  for  the  sector, 
based on a participatory process that included key stakeholders, including villagers. The thrust 
of the Policy Statement for the Development of Sustainable Rural and Micro Finance Sector is 
the development of a market-oriented, sustainable sector, which includes active private sector 
participation,  removal  of  interest  rate  caps  and  subsidies,  and  development  of  an  enabling 
policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  framework.  The  Policy  Statement  was  endorsed  by  a  forum  of 
Provincial Vice Governors and other senior Lao officials in June 2003, by BOL in August 2003, 
and  by  the  Prime  Minister’s  Office  in  November  2003.  Subproject  4  of  the  TA  cluster  (co-
financed by FIRST) has sustained the momentum of the reform process by assisting the RMFC 
through  a  participatory  process  to  develop  a  strategy  to  promote  rural  and  microfinance 
development, and assisting BOL's Department of Supervision to develop an enabling legal and 
regulatory  framework.  The  regulatory  framework  was  officially  issued  in  June  2005,  and  the 
strategy will be issued as a first-tranche condition.

Since  2000,  the  ADB  TA  cluster  3413-LAO:  Rural  Finance  Development  has  assisted 
the  Government  to  begin  developing  a  sustainable,  market-oriented  rural  financial  system  to 
contribute to poverty reduction in Lao PDR. The TA cluster was requested by the Government 
because it recognized that weaknesses in the policy environment and institutional capacity were 
major constraints to developing sustainable rural and microfinance and expanding outreach. 
 

With the TA’s assistance, the Government's Rural and Microfinance Committee (RMFC) 
has prepared a “Policy Statement for the Development of a Sustainable Rural and Microfinance 
Sector”,  which  was  endorsed  by  the  Prime  Minister’s  Office  in  November  2003,  and  presents 
the  Government’s  vision  of  a  diverse,  sustainable,  market-oriented  sector  that  will  expand 
significantly  to  contribute  to  the  Government’s  National  Poverty  Eradication  Program  (NPEP). 
The TA has also (i) assisted the RMFC to develop a draft National Strategy to promote rural and
