framework  that  will  facilitate  the  establishment  of  new  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  and 
ensure the development of a viable rural and microfinance sector.  
 

The  draft  National  Strategy  has  five  basic  components:  (i)  to  create  an  enabling  policy 
framework;  (ii)  to  create  a  sound  prudential  regulatory  and  supervisory  environment;  (iii)  to 
create  a  market-oriented  state-owned  sector;  (iv)  to  create  a  diverse  and  competitive  private 
microfinance  sector;  and  (v)  to  create  a  supportive  non-prudential  regulatory  environment. 
Under part (iv) the Strategy calls for (a) allowing pilot testing and providing start-up support to 
private  rural  and  microfinance  institutions,  (b)  encouraging  a  diversity  of  microfinance 
institutions that operate autonomously and sustainably, (c) creating a practitioners’ association, 
and  (d)  fostering  the  development  of  full-scale  private  institutions.  Therefore,  the  Microfinance 
Fund  and  its  Management  Unit  are  designed  to  assist  the  Government  to  realize  its  policy, 
vision,  and  strategy  for  the  sector,  in  particular  to  promote  the  piloting,  establishment,  and 
operation of sustainable, best-practice MFIs to serve a diverse population, including women and 
ethnic groups, and thereby contribute to the Government’s poverty reduction goals. 
 

Innovation  

4. 
 
Microfinance  is  at  an  embryonic  stage  in  Lao  PDR.  Outreach  is  extremely  limited,  and 
the  poor  in  particular  have  little  access  to  formal  financial  services.  Thirty-nine  percent  of  the 
country’s population is poor, and over 90% of the poor live in rural areas. However, only about 
15%  of  Lao  households  have  access  to  formal  financial  sources,  and  the  vast  majority  are  in 
non-poor  urban  areas.  In  the  absence  of  access  to  formal  sources  of  credit,  the  poor  rely  on 
informal  sources  of  finance,  including  relatives,  friends,  merchants,  and  moneylenders,  who 
charge interest rates as high as 240% per year (20% per month). The Government's policy to 
support  access  to  rural  finance  has  been  implemented  primarily  by  the  Agriculture  Promotion 
Bank  (APB),  which  has  conducted  directed  lending  at  below-market  interest  rates.  APB's 
outreach  has  been  limited  because  it  depends  on  the  limited  funding  available  from  the 
Government  and  donors,  and  because  its  policies,  inefficient  and  subsidized  operations,  and 
weak financial condition prevent it from mobilizing commercial funding. APB has been operating 
at  a  significant  loss  since  it  was  established  in  1993,  representing  a  substantial  cost  to  the 
Government budget. It is now recognized that APB’s directed lending policies have distorted the 
rural  finance  system  and  resulted  in  misallocation  of  resources,  low  deposit  mobilization,  and 
crowding  out  of  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  and  other  banks.  Moreover,  the  Lao  and 
international  experience  demonstrates  that  the  non-poor  are  the  main  beneficiaries  of 
subsidized  interest  rates  since  they  have  greater  access  and  can  absorb  larger  loans.  When 
subsidized  loans  are  not  available,  the  poor  are  willing  to  pay  market  interest  rates,  and  they 
tend to value sustained access more than a low interest rate. Hence, the poor in particular will 
benefit from sustainable MFIs. 

 
Based  on  their  recognition  of  APB’s  weaknesses,  the  Lao  authorities  have  begun 
restructuring  APB,  with  ADB  support,  to  transform  it  into  a  sustainable,  market-oriented  rural 
finance  institution.  The  plan  includes  phasing  out  directed  lending  and  interest  rate  subsidies 
over 3 years. The Government has also adopted a new Policy Statement for Sustainable Rural 
and  Microfinance,  which  includes  a  policy  to  support  the  development  of  sustainable  private 
initiatives.

In  this  context  of  Lao  PDR’s  transition  to  a  market  economy,  the  Government’s  new 
focus on building sustainable market-oriented MFIs and phasing out its directed-credit approach 
is innovative. Such a step has been difficult even in more developed market economies, so its 
occurrence in Lao PDR is extraordinary. Similarly, the creation of a special Microfinance Fund 
(MFF)  to  provide  start-up  grants  and  seed  capital  to  private  MFIs  is  innovative  and  is  a 
demonstration  of  the  Government’s  commitment  to  its  stated  policies.  A  number  of  bilateral 
donors  and  international  NGOs  have  begun  to  express  some  interest  in  investing  in 
microfinance  in  Lao  PDR,  now  that  the  policy  environment  is  improving.  However,  they  also 
remain  skeptical  because  of  past  practices,  so  they  are  eager  to  see  a  demonstration  of  the 
Government’s commitment. Preliminary results of an ongoing survey indicates that there would 
be a strong demand for grants from the MFF. The MFF will therefore catalyze private-sector-led 
growth in sustainable, market-oriented MFIs that are a proven method for reducing poverty. The 
poor in remote areas, particularly women and ethnic groups, will benefit because MFIs serving 
them will be given preference for matching grants, subject to meeting the other eligibility criteria, 
including a focus on sustainability and best practices. Similarly, MFIs (e.g., savings and credit 
unions) that develop innovative, flexible products and services that are specifically designed for 
the poor will be given preference. 

 
Similarly,  outreach  activities  under  the  MFF  (e.g.,  workshops  and  trainings)  will 
disseminate  best  practice  principles  throughout  the  country,  both  among  officials  and 
practitioners. Hence, the entire project is an innovative approach to stimulate the creation and 
growth  of  private  MFIs  in  Lao  PDR,  including  in  the  poorer  remote  areas.  The  MFF  and 
associated  activities  will  ensure  that  the  momentum  of  reforms  built  up  with  the  assistance  of 
the  ADB  TA  cluster  will  continue.  A  more  efficient,  diverse,  competitive,  and  market-oriented 
rural finance system will increase access to financial services and significantly expand income-
generating opportunities, generate employment, and reduce poverty. 
 

5.  

Sustainability 

Sustainability will be achieved in three ways.  

 
 
 

First,  the  focus  of  the  Microfinance  Fund’s  activities  will  be  on  supporting  the  creation 
and growth of sustainable, private, market-oriented MFIs that follow international best practices. 
Hence,  the  MFF  will  contribute  to  the  establishment  of  a  sustainable  microfinance  sector.  Of 
particular  importance  in  this  effort  will  be  the  consolidation,  on  a  pilot  basis,  of  some  of  the 
village savings and credit groups (VSCGs) that have been established in some 1600 villages in 
Lao  PDR.  Most  of  these  are  either  non-functioning  now  or  are  unsustainable  because  of 
inefficient  credit  and  management  systems  that  have  focused  on  channeling  limited,  cheap 
credit to members. The project will therefore consolidate a sample of these VSCGs into larger 
local MFIs, which may then serve as a model for future consolidation of other VSCGs.  

 
Second, if the Fund proves successful and is needed to catalyze further growth following 
the JPFR grant, then it will be in a position to attract additional funding from international donors 
and/or  the Government.  In  such  a case,  the MFFMU  would  be  transformed  into  a  legal  “fund” 
under Lao law, with representation on its board from donors and shareholders. The MFFMU and 
systems  established  with  the  JFPR  grant,  along  with  additional  donor  support,  will  enable  the 
MFF and MFFMU to sustain its operations.  

 
Third, project activities include the preparation of the terms of reference and prospectus 
for carrying out a feasibility study to establish a private (or public-private partnership) national-
level MFI. Among the options that this study would consider would be to transform the MFF and

MFFMU into a national-level MFI, and the study would include a financing plan to attract donor 
support. For example, bilateral donors and international NGOs may be invited to take an equity 
stake in the transformed MFF / national MFI, and may do so in a public-private partnership with 
the Lao Government, and participating MFIs that have benefited from the MFF could be invited 
to join the national MFI as branches.  

 
In these three cases, the focus of this project is on creating MFIs that will be sustainable 
over the long-term. Such a focus on sustainability is the best way to ensure that the poor have 
the continued access to the financial services that they need. 

 
Moreover,  in  terms  of  environmental  sustainability,  although  loans  from  participating 
MFIs to clients are expected to be small and therefore have insignificant environmental impacts, 
all participating MFIs will be required to have sound environmental policies, including following 
Lao  environmental  laws  and  the  conduct  of  environmental  due  diligence  for  loans  that  have 
potential environmental effects.

7.  

Coordination 

Coordination  with  JICA,  the  World  Bank,  IMF,  and  other  donors  has  been  close  and 
frequent.  As  discussed  in  part  6  above,  a  series  of  workshops  on  the  Policy  Statement, 
Strategy,  and  regulatory  framework  have  included  the  active  participation  of  many  donors, 
including  JICA,  the  World  Bank,  and  IMF.  The  World  Bank,  the  international  NGO  Concern 
Worldwide,  and  the  Financial  Reform  Strengthening  Initiative  (FIRST,  a  consortium  of  several 
multilateral and bilateral donors) contributed financing to organize some of the workshops (ADB 
TA and the Government provided the balance of workshop costs). ADB, World Bank, and IMF 
have cooperated and collaborated extremely closely over the past 3 years in developing a long-
term financial sector reform program for Lao PDR, of which rural and microfinance is an integral 
component—rural and microfinance is the subject of separate components in the World Bank’s 
Financial Management Adjustment Credit and in ADB’s Banking Sector Reform Program Loan, 
both  approved  in  2002.  AusAid  and  Swedish  International  Development  Agency  (SIDA)  have 
contributed to the program by financing audits of the state-owned commercial banks, including 
APB.  JICA  has  made  an  important  contribution  to  the  program  through  its  support  for 
macroeconomic  management  and  state-owned  enterprise  reform  through  the  MAPS  program. 
ADB has hosted donor roundtable discussions in Lao PDR to brief donors on ADB activities, to 
be updated on their program activities, and to coordinate overall efforts to reform the rural and 
microfinance sector.

Rationale for Grant Funding versus ADB Lending 

The  JFPR  grant  will  complement  a  Sector  Development  Loan  for  the  rural  and 
microfinance sector, and has been designed in a way to reflect the objectives and policies of the 
Government  of  Lao  PDR.  The  Government  generally  seeks  loan  funds  for  investments  in 
concrete goods and services, while preferring grant financing for training, capacity building, and 
project support. Despite this preference, the Government will be borrowing from the ADB loan to 
continue  the  APB  restructuring  plan  and  upgrade  BOL’s  capacity  to  supervise  MFIs—both 
components  are  mostly  training  and  capacity  building.  The  program  loan  would  ensure 
continued improvements in the policy and regulatory environment to support the establishment 
and operation of private MFIs. The JFPR grant would finance complementary training, outreach 
for MFI practitioners and Government officials, as well as create a Microfinance Fund (MFF) and

promotion of sustainable private MFIs focused on the poor.

Grant Development Objective and Expected Key Performance Indicators 

Grant Development Objective (GDO):  
The grant development objective is to contribute to sustained poverty reduction and economic growth in 
Lao  PDR  by  improving  the  efficiency  and  market-orientation  of  the  country’s  primary  rural  financial 
institution,  the  Agriculture  Promotion  Bank  (APB).  While  the  Government  will  use  an  ADB  loan  to 
purchase new hardware and software for APB and finance its turnkey installation, the JFICT grant would 
finance  the  associated  assistance  to  APB  to  (i)  oversee  and  manage  the  specification  and  turnkey 
bidding process and the turnkey implementation contract, (ii) build capacity in APB to undertake its role in 
these processes and subsequently roll-out systems throughout its network, and (iii) conduct training and 
capacity building to use the new system. APB’s ICT and MIS lag far behind similar banks in the region, 
making an ICT and MIS upgrade necessary to bridge the digital divide between APB and more modern 
banks.  The  upgrade  will  also  enable  APB  to  be  fully  integrated  into  the  Lao  banking  system,  and 
specifically  meet  its  reporting  requirements  to  the  Bank  of  Lao  PDR  (BOL,  the  central  bank).  As  Lao 
PDR’s primary rural financial institution with the country’s largest branch network, APB accounts for the 
vast  majority  of  loans  to  rural  clients,  and  specifically  targets  poor  farmers  and  rural  micro  and  small 
entrepreneurs.  Therefore,  improvements  in  APB’s  ICT  and  MIS will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction and 
economic growth by (i) reducing the costs and improving the efficiency of delivery of financial services to 
APB’s  rural  clients,  thus  allowing  it  to  expand  outreach  to  poor  clients  on  a  sustainable  basis,  and  (ii) 
improving APB’s internal governance by enabling it to improve financial transparency and ensure more 
effective prudential oversight by BOL.  
Expected Key Performance Indicators: 

Finalized user requirements and technical specifications (by month 3) 
Turnkey contract signed (by month 8) 
Turnkey contract implemented and final acceptance given (by month 14) 
Upgraded ICT systems rolled out to all APB branches (by month 24)

Genesis 

 

The  ADB  TA  cluster  3413-LAO1  for  Rural  Finance  Development  has  assisted  the 
Government  since  2000  to  begin  to  develop  a  sustainable,  market-oriented  rural  financial 
system  to  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  and  economic  growth.  Under  the  TA  cluster,  the 
Government  requested  ADB's  assistance  to  transform  the  state-owned  Agriculture  Promotion 
Bank (APB) into a sustainable, market-oriented rural financial institution. In November 2002, the 
Government adopted a new corporate vision for APB to be Lao PDR’s “premiere rural finance 
institution” and to "operate in a market-oriented, financially self-sustainable way to contribute to 
poverty  reduction  and  the  country's  economic  growth  and  prosperity."  Hence,  financially  self-
sustainable market-orientation is now the Government's chosen method for APB to contribute to 
poverty  reduction.  Moreover,  under  the  ADB  Banking  Sector  Reform  Program  Loan,2  the 
Government recommitted itself to implementing a phased operational and financial restructuring 
plan  for  APB  based  on  good  governance  principles  to  achieve  the  new  corporate  vision.  This 
commitment  has  been  reinforced  through  official  Government  policy  documents,  including  the 
recent “Policy Statement for the Development of Sustainable Rural and Micro Finance Sector” 
and the “National Poverty Eradication Program”. 

To  begin  reforming  APB,  Subproject  2  of  the  TA  cluster  (May  to  November  2002) 
conducted (i) a diagnostic review of APB to better understand its strengths and weaknesses in 
comparison  to  international  best  practice,  and  (ii)  a  financial  audit  to  better  understand  its 
financial position. Based on the findings, a Restructuring Plan was prepared. The Restructuring 
Plan  has  six  main  components:  (i)  the  removal  of  subsidies  and  the  liberalization  of  interest 
rates,  (ii)  creation  of  management  autonomy  and  the  termination  of  directed  lending, 
(iii) systematic  workout  of  non-performing  loans,  (iv)  upgrading  of  ICT  systems  and  MIS, 
(v) progressive  recapitalization  based  on  performance;  and  (vi)  a  range  of  inter-related 
institution-building  initiatives  that  support  the  key  restructuring  activities.  Under  Subproject  5 
(March 2003 to June 2004) work commenced in all of these areas except ICT and MIS, which 
was deferred because of the need to ensure funding was in place for the ICT upgrade. 

APB  lags  behind  similar  banks  in  the  region  (e.g.,  BAAC  in  Thailand,  VBARD  in 
Vietnam, BRI in Indonesia, and RDB in Cambodia) in terms of its ICT and MIS. APB’s current 
ICT  environment  and  MIS  do  not  adequately  provide  any  of  the  systems  needed  in  a  modern 
bank.  Specifically:  (i)  there  is  a  lack  of  vision  and  strategy  for  ICT  development,  and 
consequently no effective plan or budget provision; (ii) the mandate of the ICT unit is not clear is 
relation to its strategic and planning functions; (iii) none of the systems currently in use at APB 
are able to provide a basic customer information system, making effective risk management and 
performance assessment impossible; (iv) any  new banking products and services can only be 
developed when a comprehensive and integrated core banking system is in place; (v) the ICT 
staff capacity is inadequate for APB’s current and future needs; (vi) ICT policy and procedures 
are  not  documented  and  not  enforceable;  (vii)  ICT  security  is  weak  and  there  is  no  business 
continuity or disaster recovery plan; and (vii) software in many instances is not licensed and is 
thus  unsupported.  Additionally,  there  are  shortcomings  in  the  management  reporting  system 
that make it of limited use for management decision making; the report generation capacity of 
present software is inadequate for management reporting; current reports are not differentiated 
by user or management level; and the reporting system does not measure bank performance. 
Moreover,  because  APB  has  gone  effectively  unsupervised  by  BOL  until  now,  the  current

4. 

Sustainability 

 

Sustainability of APB’s ICT and MIS upgrade is linked to the sustainability of the overall 
APB  reform  and  restructuring  program,  which  has  been  developed  since  2000  with  ADB  TA 
assistance under TA cluster 3413-LAO: Rural  Finance Development.  Through the ongoing TA 
cluster  activities,  strong  Government  ownership  of  the  reform  program  has  been  established 
(not only for APB’s reforms, but also for microfinance reforms). Indeed, the primary objective of 
the APB restructuring plan is to transform APB into a sustainable, market-oriented rural finance 
institution—in  November  2002,  the  Government  adopted  a  new  corporate  vision  for  APB  to 
"operate in a market-oriented, financially self-sustainable way to contribute to poverty reduction 
and the country's economic growth and prosperity." 
 

In  this  context  it  is  noteworthy  that  APB  was  originally  established  in  1993  as  a  policy 
bank  to  channel  subsidized  credit  to  Lao  farmers.  However,  APB's  outreach  has  been  limited 
because  it  depends  on  the  limited  funding  available  from  the  Government  and  donors,  and 
because its policies, inefficient and subsidized operations, and weak financial condition prevent 
it from mobilizing commercial funding. APB has been operating at a significant loss since it was 
established  in  1993,  representing  a  substantial  cost  to  the  Government  budget.  It  is  now 
recognized  that  APB’s  directed  lending  policies  have  distorted  the  rural  finance  system  and 
resulted  in  misallocation  of  resources,  low  deposit  mobilization,  and  crowding  out  of 
microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  and  other  banks.  Moreover,  the  Lao  and  international 
experience  demonstrates  that  the  non-poor  are  the  main  beneficiaries  of  subsidized  interest 
rates since they have greater access and can absorb larger loans. When subsidized loans are 
not available, the poor are willing to pay market interest rates, and they tend to value sustained 
access  more  than  a  low  interest  rate.  Hence,  the  poor  in  particular  will  benefit  from  a 
sustainable, market-oriented APB. 
 

Based  on  their  recognition  of  APB’s  weaknesses,  the  Lao  authorities  have  begun 
restructuring  APB,  with  ADB  support,  to  transform  it  into  a  sustainable,  market-oriented  rural 
finance  institution.  The  plan  includes  phasing  out  directed  lending  and  interest  rate  subsidies 
over  3  years,  so  that  APB  will  become  fully  financially  self-sustainable.  The  Government  has 
also adopted a new national Policy Statement for Sustainable Rural and Micro Finance, which 
includes a reaffirmation of its commitment to transform APB into a sustainable, market-oriented 
institution and to phase out interest rate subsidies.

The APB reform program, moreover, has been coordinated closely with the Lao Banking 
Sector  Reform  Program  Loan  (BSRPL,  ADB  Loan  1946-LAO),  which  was  prepared  in 
collaboration  with  the  World  Bank,  IMF,  and  other  donors.  This  overall  banking  sector  reform 
program includes a policy component calling for implementation of the APB restructuring plan. 
Moreover,  BOL’s  Banking  Sector  ICT  Strategy  calls  for  upgrading  APB’s  ICT  and  MIS. 
However,  it  must  be  noted  that  APB  has,  since  its  creation,  been  treated  differently  from  the 
State-Owned  Commercial  Banks  (SOCBs)—indeed,  APB  was  established  as  a  “policy  bank” 
rather  than  an  SOCB.  As  a  result,  it  has  been  the  subject  of  its  own  reform  program,  which, 
while coordinated with BSRPL, has also followed its own path to account for its unique situation. 
While APB’s restructuring plan calls for its treatment as an SOCB, it maintains a unique role in 
Lao PDR as the Government’s main instrument for delivering financial services to rural areas. 
As  such,  implementation  of  its  restructuring  plan  is  of  exceptional  importance  to  the 
Government,  which  is  keen  that  sustainability  and  increased  outreach  to  the  poor  go  hand-in-
hand. 
 

The proposed turnkey approach combined with subsequent capacity-building assistance 
to  APB  with  the  roll-out  of  systems  bank-wide  will  ensure  effective  implementation  and 
sustainability  of  the  new  ICT  and  MIS.  Moreover,  it  is  expected  that  the  turnkey  contract  will 
contain provisions for warranties for 12 months on equipment, 12 months on software from final 
acceptance by APB, and a requirement for a maintenance agreement to specified service levels 
for a period of five years from the end of the warranty period. Provision for the recurrent costs 
associated with systems maintenance will be incorporated into APB’s budgets for its corporate 
plan 2006-2008 and in subsequent rolling three-year corporate plans. 
 

5.  

Participatory Approach 

 
 
An  intensive  and  extensive  participatory  process  has  been  pursued  under  TA  cluster 
3413-LAO: Rural Finance Development since 2000. Subproject 1 (October 2000 to July 2001) 
included,  among  other  activities,  (i)  awareness  creation  workshops  for  local  officials  and 
practitioners,  which  reviewed  international  best  practice  in  rural  finance;  (ii)  four  guided  study 
tours  with  senior  officials  from  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  BOL,  the  Prime  Minister's  Office,  the 
Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry,  and  APB  to  sustainable  rural  finance  institutions  in  the 
region; and (iii) preparation and review of a policy and institutional issues paper through a series 
of  provincial  workshops  and  a  national  wrap-up  meeting—the  policy  and  institutional  issues 
paper  identified  policy  reforms  needed  in  the  economic  and  legal  framework  and  institutional 
strategies to address the current constraints in rural finance. The overall impact of subproject 1 
was  positive—knowledge  of  key  issues  and  best  practices  in  rural  and  microfinance  were 
enhanced,  as  evidenced  by  the  quality  of  policy  dialogue  that  has  ensued  in  preparing 
subsequent initiatives. Subproject 2 (May to  December 2002) conducted a diagnostic study of 
APB on 12 topics: (i) governance; (ii) strategic planning; (iii) organizational structure; (iv) human 
resources management; (v) pricing policies and procedures; (vi) credit policies and procedures; 
(vii)  risk  management  policies  and  procedures;  (viii)  products  and  demand;  (ix)  compliance 
review;  (x)  financial  and  accounting  systems;  (xi)  management  information  systems;  and 
(xii) financial  analysis.  The  diagnostic  study  also  included  the  first  external  audit  of  APB.  The 
findings  were  reviewed  by  the  Government  and  ADB  and  discussed  in  a  3-day  workshop  in 
September  2002.  This  led  to  the  production  of  a  draft  restructuring  plan  for  APB  in  October 
2002. Following a review of the draft by the Government and ADB, a final plan was agreed on in 
December 2002. Implementation of the restructuring plan began under subproject 5. Moreover, 
subproject 4 assisted the Government to prepare: (i) a national policy statement on sustainable 
rural  and  microfinance, (ii)  draft  national  strategy  for  rural  and  microfinance  development,  and 
(iii)  draft  regulations  for  microfinance  and  prudential  regulations  for  APB.  These  three

Rationale for Grant Funding versus ADB Lending 

The  JFICT  grant  will  complement  a  Sector  Development  Loan  for  the  rural  and 
microfinance sector, and has been designed in a way to reflect the objectives and policies of the 
Government  of  Lao  PDR.  The  Government  generally  seeks  loan  funds  for  investments  in 
concrete goods and services, while preferring grant financing for training, capacity building, and 
project support. Despite this preference, the Government will be borrowing from the ADB loan to

continue  the  APB  restructuring  plan  and  upgrade  BOL’s  capacity  to  supervise  MFIs—both 
components  are  mostly  training  and  capacity  building.  The  Government  will  also  borrow  to 
purchase the hardware and software for APB’s ICT and MIS upgrade. The program loan would 
ensure  continued  improvements  in  the  policy  and  regulatory  environment  to  support  the 
establishment and operation of private MFIs.  
 

The JFICT grant would finance complementary support to APB to finalize ICT and MIS 
specifications, to manage the bidding process, and to conduct training and capacity building in 
APB to implement its new system, strategy, and procedures. Given the Government’s tight fiscal 
position, the amount the Government is already borrowing for other activities, and the poverty 
focus of the proposed JFICT activities, it would be difficult for the Government to borrow for the 
proposed  activities.  However,  the  overall  package  demonstrates  the  Government  commitment 
to transforming APB into a sustainable, market-oriented rural finance institution.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Lao PDR: 
 
The National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES), approved by the National Assembly in October 
2003, identifies access to rural finance as critical to reducing poverty and promoting economic growth. Sustainable 
access to rural finance is required to support and expand economic activities in the rural areas, where 90% of the 
poor live.  
 
At  present,  the  rural  financial  sector  in  Lao  PDR  is  poorly  developed.  While  there  is  demand  for  rural  financial 
services  (i)  to  support  investment  in  livestock  production,  agriculture  diversification,  and  other  non-farm  income-
generating activities; (ii) to finance household emergencies and consumption; and (iii) for secure savings facilities, 
access is limited. The “Banking and Financial Sector in Lao PDR – Financial Sector Note” of 2002 prepared by the 
Bank of Lao PDR, ADB, and the World Bank, estimates that only 20% of the 800,000 households in Lao PDR have 
access  to  some  form  of  formal  or  semi-formal  financial  services  provided  by  commercial  banks,  semi-formal 
microfinance  initiatives,  or  village  based  funds.  The  remaining  80%  have  no  access  to  formal  financial  services. 
Financial services are mainly available in urban areas and to the better off. In the absence of formal rural financial 
services, the poor in rural areas often rely on family, friends, traders, moneylenders, and other informal sources. 
The  interest  rates  charged  for  borrowing  from  informal  sources  are  significantly  higher  than  rates  from  formal 
sources, hindering investments by the poor and further impoverishing them. Furthermore, those in the rural areas 
and the poor hold most of their wealth in risky assets such as livestock, gold, or other in-kind items. Only 1 to 5% of 
rural savings are held as bank deposits. Hence, the level of financial intermediation is extremely low.  
 
One  reason  for  the  limited  outreach  of  rural  financial  service  is  the  highly  dispersed  population  and  limited 
infrastructure, resulting in high cost of financial intermediation and information access in rural areas. This challenge 
to expanding rural financial services has been aggravated by the Agriculture Promotion Bank’s (APB's) operations, 
which  have  tended  to  distort  the  rural  financial  system.  APB  is  the  Government’s  main  instrument  for  delivering 
formal rural financial services. However, APB's operations have been inefficient because of the substantial policy 
lending carried out on behalf of the Government, its subsidized interest rates, and its common practice of rolling 
over  loans,  dependence  on  donor  and  Government  funding  for  its  operations,  and  involvement  in  non-financial 
services. Given the subsidized nature of its operations and its weak financial position, APB has not been able to 
mobilize  commercial  funding  to  expand  its  outreach.  As  the  main  player  in  rural  finance  sector,  APB's  operation 
has been crowding out other microfinance institutions—in areas where APB operates, this effect is direct as APB 
undercuts  potentially  sustainable  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs);  in  other  areas,  where  APB  may  not  operate, 
APB has created unrealistic expectations among borrowers about the cost of credit, making it difficult for MFIs to 
charge  sustainable  interest  rates.  Rural  financial  services  have  been  further  constrained  by  unclear  legal  and 
regulatory  framework  for  microfinance,  making  the  establishment  and  operation  of  MFIs  difficult  and  subject  to 
arbitrary interference from officials.  
 
The  Rural  Financial  Sector  Development  Program  focuses  on  (i)  improving  the  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory 
framework  for  microfinance  operations;  (ii)  supporting  the  ongoing  restructuring  of  APB,  transforming  it  from  a 
subsidized  policy  lending  institution  to  a  market  oriented,  financially  self-sustainable  commercial  bank  with 
continued  focus  on  rural  areas,  in  line  with  the  goals  of  the  NGPES;  and  (iii)  supporting  new  microfinance 
institutions  in  rural  areas  through  establishment  of  a  Microfinance  Fund  (MFF)—MFF  will  support  microfinance 
initiatives  that  contribute  directly  and  indirectly  to  increased  income  and  improved  livelihoods  of  the  poor, 
particularly in the rural areas. The combined program and project loan components will strengthen the rural finance 
sector.  It  will  foster  sustainable  access  to  rural  financial  services  by  the  rural  poor,  who  currently  have  limited 
access to formal financial service. Accordingly, sustained access to rural finance will enable the rural poor to invest 
in, and take advantage of, the opportunities in farm and non-farm income generating activities.

What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Existing information indicates that the number of poor with access to formal financial services is limited while the 
demand  is high. A household survey  undertaken in  early  2004 confirm the limited access to formal  and  informal 
financial  services,  the  need  and  demand  for  formal  rural  financial  services,  attitude  towards  different  types  and 
providers  of  financial  services,  and  ability  and  willingness  to  pay  for  services  and  repay  borrowing.  Analysis  is 
being further disaggregated by poverty status, family size, educational attainment, gender, and ethnic groupings. 
Preliminary  results  confirm  that  the  poor  have  less  access  to  formal  financial  services  than  the  less  poor.  This 
information will help determine what types of microfinance institutions and financial services may be most effective 
in  reaching  the  poor  in  rural  areas  and  meeting  their  needs,  and  thus  should  be  supported  through  the 
Microfinance Fund.

The  Program  and  Project  loans  will  involve  the  participation  of  the  Bank  of  Lao  PDR  (BOL),  APB,  other 
Government  ministries  and  agencies,  NGOs,  various  funding  agencies  providing  microfinance  services  in  rural

implement  an  improved  framework,  was  undertaken  in  2003-04.  A  sample  household  survey  was  undertaken  to 
assess the demand and need for rural financial services, attitudes towards different financial services, and ability to 
pay for services and to repay any borrowings. The results are being disaggregated by family size, gender, ethnic 
groupings,  poverty  status,  and  educational  attainment.  It  will  enable  better  understanding  of  the  types  of  rural 
financial  services  required  and  appropriate  mode  of  service  delivery.  A  comprehensive  review  of  existing  rural 
finance providers, focusing on NGOs, is also taking place to provide a comprehensive picture of the status of rural 
finance sector.

The  policy  framework  for  rural  finance  including  the  Policy  Statement  for  the  Development  of  Sustainable  Rural 
and  Micro  Finance  Sector  and  the  Strategy  and  Action  Plan  for  the  Promotion  of  Sustainable  Rural  and 
Microfinance  has  been  prepared  through  a  participatory  process  involving  the  Government,  donors,  NGOs, 
practitioners,  and  clients.  The  restructuring  of  APB,  which  was  initiated  by  ADB  technical  assistance  and  will 
continue under the Program and Project Loans, is being undertaken in consultation with Government, key donors, 
NGOs,  and  staff  of  APB.  The  MFF  supported  under  the  Project  Loan  will  promote  the  expanded  participation  of 
MFIs as providers of financial services in rural areas. The MFF will support MFIs that promote equitable access to

D.  Gender Development 

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Women have an important role in ensuring the livelihoods of their families. According to the LECS II (1997-1998), 
and analysis of gender and time use, women work more than men on income generating activities and household 
labor.  According  to  the  Study  on  Integrating  Human  Concerns  in  Local  Development  in  Three  Provinces  of  Lao 
PDR  (April  2002)  prepared  by  the  Committee  for  Planning  and  Cooperation  in  partnership  with  United  Nations 
Center  for  Regional  Development,  women  identified  economic  threats  as  a  key  source  of  vulnerability.  Thus, 
ensuring women's sustainable access to financial services will enable them to cope with household emergencies 
and economic threats, as well as to invest in income generating activities that benefit the family.  
 
However,  given  the  noticeable  differences  between  men  and  women  in  their  education  attainment,  public  role, 
family  attitudes  and  responsibilities,  women  generally  have  less  direct  access  to  formal  financial  services.  The 
Program  and  Project  loans  are  expected  to  strengthen  the  rural  financial  sector,  which  will  encourage 
establishment and sustained operations of MFIs that will serve the needs of the rural poor, both men and women. 
Given  the  constraints  faced  by  women  to  access  formal  financial  services,  the  MFF  has  an  important  role  in 
promoting  MFIs  that  target  women.  Accordingly,  piloting  and  supporting  microfinance  initiatives  that  promote 
equitable participation of women will be prioritized, subject to the MFI’s focus on sustainability.
